title: How to Make Blueberry Waffles

steps.headline: Beat the egg whites in a small bowl with an electric mixer.
steps.description: Blend until stiff peaks begin to form. Set aside.

steps.headline: Combine the dry ingredients together in a large bowl.
steps.description: Whisk the flour, salt, and baking powder until well-combined. Set aside for later use.

steps.headline: Beat the wet ingredients in a separate large bowl.
steps.description: Whisk the milk, egg yolks, and butter together.

steps.headline: Pour the wet ingredients and egg whites into the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Mix well with a whisk, folding until the waffle batter is smooth, moistened, and doesn't have anymore flour streaks.

steps.headline: Fold in the blueberries and mix once more.
Preheat your waffle iron, following your manufacturer’s instructions.
steps.description: Spread melted butter over the waffle iron as well.

steps.headline: Make the blueberry sauce.
steps.description: As you wait for the waffle iron to heat up, place the blueberries, honey, and ¼ cup of orange juice into a small saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil and then slowly add in the cornstarch and the rest of the juice. Stir frequently until the blueberry sauce begins to form. The blueberry sauce will usually take about two minutes to thicken.

steps.headline: Pour the waffle batter onto the waffle iron.
steps.description: Cook both sides for about two minutes until golden brown. Repeat until there is no more batter. As you make more waffles, you can keep the remaining waffles warm by placing them in the oven on the lowest temperature.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Drizzle the blueberry sauce over the waffles and add any remaining fresh berries, if desired. Enjoy!

text: Basic Blueberry Waffles Beat the egg whites in a small bowl with an electric mixer. Blend until stiff peaks begin to form. Set aside. Combine the dry ingredients together in a large bowl. Whisk the flour, salt, and baking powder until well-combined. Set aside for later use. Beat the wet ingredients in a separate large bowl. Whisk the milk, egg yolks, and butter together. Pour the wet ingredients and egg whites into the dry ingredients. Mix well with a whisk, folding until the waffle batter is smooth, moistened, and doesn't have anymore flour streaks. Fold in the blueberries and mix once more.  Preheat your waffle iron, following your manufacturer’s instructions. Spread melted butter over the waffle iron as well. Make the blueberry sauce. As you wait for the waffle iron to heat up, place the blueberries, honey, and ¼ cup of orange juice into a small saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil and then slowly add in the cornstarch and the rest of the juice. Stir frequently until the blueberry sauce begins to form. The blueberry sauce will usually take about two minutes to thicken. Pour the waffle batter onto the waffle iron. Cook both sides for about two minutes until golden brown. Repeat until there is no more batter. As you make more waffles, you can keep the remaining waffles warm by placing them in the oven on the lowest temperature. Serve. Drizzle the blueberry sauce over the waffles and add any remaining fresh berries, if desired. Enjoy! Belgian Blueberry Waffles Preheat your waffle iron following your manufacturer’s instructions. Spread melted butter over the waffle iron as well. Combine the dry ingredients together in a large bowl. Whisk the flour, salt, sugar, and baking powder until well-combined. Set aside for later use. Beat the wet ingredients in a separate large bowl. Whisk the milk, eggs, and oil together until properly beaten. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Mix well with a whisk, folding until the waffle batter is smooth, moistened, and doesn't have anymore flour streaks. Fold in the blueberries and mix once more.  Pour the waffle batter onto the waffle iron. Cook both sides for about two minutes until golden brown. Repeat until there is no more batter. As you make more waffles, you can keep the remaining waffles warm by placing them in the oven on the lowest temperature. Serve. Spread melted butter over the waffle iron as well. Beat the wet ingredients in a large bowl. Whisk the milk, eggs, butter, and sour cream together until properly beaten. Set aside for later use. Sift the dry ingredients together in a separate large bowl. Sift the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and sugar until the mixture is light and fluffy. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients. Mix well with a whisk, folding until the waffle batter is smooth, moistened, and doesn't have anymore flour streaks. Fold in the blueberries and mix once more.  Pour the waffle batter onto the waffle iron. Cook both sides for about two minutes until golden brown. Repeat until there is no more batter. As you make more waffles, you can keep the remaining waffles warm by placing them in the oven on the lowest temperature. Serve. Add in the milk, vanilla extract, and coconut oil. Mix well with a whisk until properly beaten. Fold in the blueberries and mix once more.  Pour the waffle batter onto the waffle iron. Cook both sides for about two minutes until golden brown. Repeat until there is no more batter. As you make more waffles, you can keep the remaining waffles warm by placing them in the oven on the lowest temperature. Serve.
